column5: In 1647 or 1648, "A Charlestown Woman" was executed for witchcraft despite maintaining her innocence, only confessing to a past theft for which she believed she had been forgiven by Christ. Her execution was part of a series of events where individuals were accused and punished for witchcraft across Massachusetts, New Haven, and Connecticut between 1646 and 1692.

In 1419, Joan of Navarre was imprisoned at Pevensey Castle after her confessor accused her of plotting to kill King Henry V with witchcraft. Her fortune was seized, and she remained in captivity until her release in 1422.
Elizabeth was in sanctuary at Westminster Abbey when accusations of witchcraft were being publicly used against her and her family.

In 1441, Eleanor Cobham was accused of treasonable necromancy after consulting astrologers who predicted King Henry VI’s illness, leading to a highly publicized trial. Found guilty of witchcraft and conspiracy, she was forced to perform public penance, divorced from her husband, and condemned to life imprisonment.
Evidence of Jacquetta's witchcraft was brought to Warwick Castle - it was a small metal man-of-arms, broken in half and fastend with wire!

Lambe’s reputation as a “devilish” sorcerer grew alongside ever-stranger stories of storms, charms, and conjured phantoms, until frightened Londoners viewed him as both mountebank and menace. Their fear hardened into fury after the notorious assault on young Joan Seager, and when court favour shielded him from the scaffold, a mob outside the Fortune finally delivered its own sentence in stones.

Joan Flower and her daughters Margaret and Philippa, servants at Belvoir Castle, were accused of witchcraft in 1618 and blamed for the deaths of two young heirs. Joan died on the way to trial after supposedly choking on bread, and the daughters confessed and were executed, becoming the centre of a well-known Lincolnshire witch legend

Arminda de Jesus, was brutally beaten and burnt alive in the village of Soalhães (Lugar de Oliveira). This tragic event took place on or around 25 February 1933, long after the era of historical witch trials, and was carried out by local villagers who believed she was possessed and needed to be purged by fire.
